entry.title: SAP Activate Playbook explained
entry.content:
SAP Activate enables program excellence in SAFe® environments by combining the strengths of SAP-specific implementation methodology with the principles of the Scaled Agile Framework. While SAP Activate provides clear guardrails for agile SAP program execution, solution-specific content, agile product delivery, and team and technical agility, SAFe® addresses organizational agility, enterprise solution delivery, and scaling agile ways of working across teams in parallel. The interaction of both approaches creates a consistent process model that combines scale, governance and speed and thus enables an efficient, high-quality and sustainably agile SAP transformation.

 

The focus is on building and continuously innovating an intelligent, sustainable enterprise through the targeted dovetailing of both approaches. It addresses key questions, including how SAFe® and SAP Activate can be optimally coordinated, how they can jointly support digital transformation, and how to get started with SAP Activate within a SAFe® environment.

SAP Activate covers the full lifecycle from Discover to Run and uses Scrum as a team-level execution framework to ensure iterative and value-driven execution. SAFe complements® this approach by addressing the organizational, technical and strategic dimensions of agile transformation from Essential to Large Solution to Portfolio and Full, depending on the scaling needs. Together, both approaches enable a consistent alignment of strategy, portfolio, product development and implementation, thus creating an integrated basis for the successful and scalable implementation of complex SAP programs.

 

SAP Activate and the Scaled Agile Framework are based on a common agile mindset and share key principles that enable consistent and effective implementation. Both approaches focus on the incremental delivery of added value in order to provide early usable results and reduce risks. Consistent timeboxing and a clear team focus in each iteration create planning security and accelerate implementation. This is complemented by the close involvement of business stakeholders and the use of a common language that ensures transparency, understanding and smooth collaboration across teams and levels.

 

The core values of SAFe® form the content bracket for the implementation of agile SAP programs and are concretely operationalized by SAP Activate. Alignment ensures that strategy, business goals and execution are aligned throughout, while Built-In Quality anchors quality as an integral part of development from the very beginning. Transparency creates clear visibility into progress, risks and dependencies at all levels, and program execution focuses on the reliable and continuous delivery of value. SAP Activate translates these values into structured phases, roles, artifacts, and practices, ensuring that SAFe® principles are implemented effectively and sustainably in the SAP context.

 

The sprint-based agile configuration approach in SAP Activate consistently relies on timeboxing and a clear focus of the team per iteration. Implementation takes place in short, completed configuration cycles that include configuration, review, testing, and transport or deployment. The basis of the sprint content is a prioritized backlog that is derived from the fit-to-standard results. Each Sprint delivers fully tested results, which are validated in Sprint Reviews together with the business users to ensure that the business requirements are met. Test-ready functionalities are transported from the development system to the test system in a structured manner, with modern CI/CD approaches supporting continuous development via SAP BTP and SAP Cloud Transport Management. User stories, configuration tasks, and progress are controlled transparently via the SAP ALM tools.

 

The close involvement of business users is a central success principle of SAP Activate in combination with SAFe® and extends over the entire life cycle of the solution. Already in the Discover phase, departments contribute to the foundation of the initial backlog through business scenarios, solution mapping and strategic guardrails. In Prepare and Explore, business and IT work closely together in fit-to-standard reviews and workshops to evaluate processes, specify requirements, enable rapid feedback, and continuously develop the ART backlog. During Realize and Deploy, the focus is on incremental implementation in short sprints, regular reviews and the active participation of the business teams in acceptance and progress evaluation. In the run phase, this interaction is continued through structured feedback, benchmarking and participation in SAP innovation formats and forms the basis for sustainable optimization and continuous value realization.

 

SAP Activate and SAFe® create a uniform basis for collaboration, control and implementation through the consistent use of a common language. Both are built on agile principles and Scrum as a foundation and use common concepts such as team and ART backlogs, sprints, iterations and incremental releases with continuous integration and release on demand. Uniform role models, from cross-functional teams to clearly defined responsibilities, ensure transparency and reliability in cooperation. This is complemented by a coordinated program and organization setup, standardized artifacts such as fit-to-standard and best-practice content, and a synchronized cadence for sprints and releases. This common terminology and structure reduces complexity, improves alignment across teams and levels, and enables consistent, scalable implementation of SAP programs.

 

The example of an SAP Agile Project Team shows a cross-functional Scrum team with an optimal size of about 7 ± 2 people, which combines all the professional and technical skills required for implementation. The focus is on the classic Scrum roles of Product Owner and Scrum Master, supplemented by Business Process, SAP Function, Application, Authorization, Test, Training and Technical Experts, who jointly assume end-to-end responsibility for delivery. Supportive roles such as Agile Coach, UX Experts, Architecture, Technical and Operational Support functions work across teams and ensure quality, consistency and scalability. In larger programs, multiple Scrum teams are coordinated via a Scrum of Scrums or SAFe® mechanisms to manage dependencies, create transparency, and ensure coordinated program execution.

 

SAP Activate enables program excellence in SAFe® environments by seamlessly integrating with SAFe practices, governance structures, and techniques and extending them with SAP-specific approaches. Through proven methodologies, guides, and accelerators, SAP Activate supports faster, more flexible, and at the same time controlled delivery of SAP solutions to business. The integration takes place along four central operating principles: incremental value delivery, close involvement of business users, consistent timeboxing with a clear team focus in each iteration, and the use of a common language across roles, artifacts, and levels. This combination creates the foundation for scalable agility, reliable program execution, and sustainable value realization, and transitions to a detailed playbook for specific SAFe fields of action.

 

Playbook: How to leverage SAP Activate within SAFe organizations

 

The overview of the most important terms creates a common understanding between SAP Activate and SAFe® and ensures that both approaches are interpreted and applied consistently. Central concepts such as SAP Solution and SAFe Solution each describe holistic, value-oriented solutions that are implemented either in an SAP or in a scaled agile context. Terms such as sprint and iteration stand for clearly time-limited PDCA cycles, while product backlog, solution train backlog and ART backlogs enable the structured prioritization of requirements, features and enablers. Release Scope and Release on Demand illustrate the focus on incremental, demand-based delivery of functionalities. Finally, workstreams and value streams connect operational implementation with end-to-end value creation and build the bridge between business goals, organizational structure and technical implementation.

 

SAP Activate is based on key themes that are consistently applied in SAP projects to achieve rapid and sustainable value realization. The initial focus is on the fit-to-standard and cloud mindset, which enables maximum use of pre-integrated SAP best-practice functionalities and thus significantly shortens time-to-value. At the same time, business users are involved in the entire implementation process at an early stage and consistently in order to create acceptance and actively anchor change in the business department. Implementation is done through an agile, iterative approach that supports incremental building of the solution, rapid adaptability, and consistent use of DevOps practices. In addition, SAP Activate ensures that solutions are designed and built sustainably – with an architecture and design that enables long-term development, scalability and continuous business value.

 

Below is a structured explanation of the slide "Organizations using SAFe benefit from SAP Activate" including the numbered points and their meaning. The numbering corresponds to the logic of the slide and systematically places SAP Activate added values in the SAFe® context.

Transformation Roadmap & Strategy Alignment

SAP Activate supports the derivation of a clear transformation roadmap from the corporate strategy. Goals, dependencies, and milestones are defined and synchronized with SAFe programs and value streams to deliver measurable business value.

Close involvement of business and stakeholders

Business users, sponsors and key stakeholders are actively involved throughout the entire lifecycle – from fit-to-standard to demos and tests. This increases acceptance, quality and speed of implementation.

  1. Fit-to-standard as a control mechanism

Structured fit-to-standard workshops identify requirements, prioritize them in the backlog, and reduce customer-specific variances. This reduces complexity and accelerates implementation.

  1. Incremental Value Delivery

SAP Agile teams deliver capabilities in small, usable increments. New skills are made available early, feedback is quickly integrated and time-to-value is significantly shortened.

  1. Scrum-based teamwork

SAP teams work according to Scrum with clear ceremonies, transparent planning and visible results (team boards, Kanban, SAP ALM). This supports SAFe-compliant team and ART flows.

Architecture & Technology as a Success Factor

SAP Activate embeds architecture, security, and technology principles at an early stage. This ensures scalability, stability and future viability of the solution.

SAP-specific governance & quality gates

SAP Activate complements SAFe with SAP-specific quality gates, standards, and deliverables. These ensure quality, compliance and controllability along the entire program.

Shared Services & Specialized Teams

Cross-sectional functions such as data migration, custom code management or OCM are efficiently organized as shared services and integrated into SAFe programs.

SAP UX & Change Enablement

Targeted use of SAP Fiori UX, enablement concepts, and change management measures promotes user acceptance and sustainable use of the solution.

SAP Customer COE & Operations

SAP Activate supports the establishment of a Customer Center of Excellence (COE) for operations, support, provisioning, and continuous improvement – structured and fit-to-standard.

  1. SAP ALM as a single source of truth

SAP ALM tools serve as a central platform for requirements, processes, test cases, documentation, and progress measurement – across teams and ARTs.

Organizational Agility & Adoption

SAP Activate provides concrete guidelines for organizational development, change management and adoption, thus strengthening business agility at the company level.

  1. Communities of Practice (CoP)

SAP Activate promotes CoPs on SAP-specific topics (e.g., architecture, integration, security). Knowledge is shared, standards are established and continuously developed.

Innovation & Smart Technologies

SAP solutions use integrated innovations such as analytics, automation, and AI to increase process efficiency and enable better decision-making.

 

 

In the Discover phase , the focus is on developing a clear innovation strategy and a resilient transition roadmap that is consistently aligned with the organization's strategic goals. The aim is to make the business value of the transformation transparent and to create a common vision for business and IT. Central aspects such as business and application architecture, platform and technology orientation, innovation initiatives and the concrete transition and migration plan are considered holistically. Supported by SAP tools such as the SAP Transformation Navigator or the Innovation and Optimization Pathfinder, a sound basis for decision-making is created that defines priorities, dependencies and investment priorities and sets the framework for a value-oriented, step-by-step transformation in the SAFe® and SAP Activate context.

 

The Discover Phase framework describes a structured approach to efficiently develop a detailed and resilient transformation program plan and thus lay the foundation for the subsequent SAP Activate and SAFe phases®. The starting point is the systematic take stock, in which existing business capabilities are analyzed in their current state, market standards are taken into account and business value is defined in the form of pain points and target images. Based on this, an initiative roadmap is created that describes the definition and integration of the central transformation projects.

In the next step, the big-ticket items are  identified by comparing standard SAP solution capacities, best practices and technical possibilities with the business requirements. Central design decisions on data, organization and solution architecture are made and transferred into a clear value realization plan with target image and measurement criteria.

Finally, the Jumpstart the Program serves  to launch the program operationally: A concrete deployment and implementation roadmap is defined, governance and OCM strategies including escalation paths are defined, and a viable resource and partner strategy is established. With these results, the transition to the preparation phase is clearly structured and well-prepared.

 

In  the Discover phase, the value case forms the bridge between strategic goals and concrete design decisions and ensures that the transformation is consistently geared towards measurable business value. The starting point is clearly defined strategic objectives that describe how the success of the organization or project will be measured, such as improving the customer experience, reducing costs or increasing sales. These goals are backed up with KPIs that combine both leading (predictive) and lagging metrics to transparently measure progress and impact.

On this basis, the relevant business capabilities that  need to be improved to achieve the goals are identified and  assigned to the value drivers, i.e. the levers in the areas of people, processes, data and technology. The professional responsibility clearly lies with the business owners. Finally, concrete design principles are derived from the interplay of goals, KPIs, capabilities and value drivers  , which specify how the solution should be designed for each team and department (e.g. billing, customer service, sales). These design principles translate strategic ambitions into consistent architecture, process, and execution decisions, ensuring consistent value orientation across the SAP program.

 

The slide shows the clear assignment and alignment of SAP Activate roles to the SAFe® team and program levels and illustrates how SAP Activate delivers an SAP-specific form of agile role models without breaking the SAFe structure. SAP Activate provides a detailed definition of roles and responsibilities, which  is used to establish governance, decision-making paths, and escalation mechanisms, especially in the early preparation phase.

At  the strategic level,  SAP Activate roles such as Sponsor and Steering Group in SAFe primarily correspond to the Epic Owners and the Enterprise Architect, who are responsible for strategic direction, architectural guardrails, and investment decisions together with a Board of Architects.

At  the solution level, roles such as Solution Manager and Solution Architect are assigned to the SAFe roles, which are responsible for end-to-end business scenarios, solution architecture and the content control of the solution trains. There are also overlaps with business transformation and program management, especially in coordination and prioritization across multiple ARTs.

At  the program and value stream level, SAP Activate roles such as Business Owner, Product Management, and System Architect are reflected in the corresponding SAFe roles, ensuring business responsibility, value orientation, and technical consistency. In addition, there is a clear assignment to business process owners as well as to technical architects within the Board of Architects.

The  agreement is highest at the team level: Product Owner and Scrum Master or Team Coach are identical in SAP Activate and SAFe and work 1:1 in every agile team. This ensures that SAP-specific content can be seamlessly integrated into SAFe implementation without creating additional role conflicts.

In sum, this role alignment enables clear governance, unambiguous responsibilities, and end-to-end governance from strategy to the agile team, while at the same time systematically embedding SAP-specific requirements in SAFe.

 

In an SAP project, the backlog describes  the structured and prioritized totality of all business and technical requirements that were identified during the fit-to-standard analysis and still need to be implemented. It forms the central planning and control basis for the incremental delivery of business value. The responsibility for prioritization and content orientation lies with the product owner, whereby dependencies between requirements – such as necessary basic settings or architecture requirements – must be taken into account by the project team. Each backlog item contains clear acceptance criteria ("How to demo"), which are used in iterations for technical approval. The backlog includes requirements in different granularities, which are continuously refined in the course of the project (backlog grooming) and brought to implementation maturity. For operational implementation, the overall backlog is broken down into release and team backlogs and typically managed in SAP ALM tools such as SAP Cloud ALM or SAP Solution Manager (Focused Build).

 

The backlog in SAP projects is built up in a structured and step-by-step manner, especially in the Explore phase, and prepared for implementation. The starting point is fit-to-standard workshops, in which show-and-tell sessions, standard process flows, and technical questions are used to identify requirements, record customer feedback, and work out deviations from the SAP standard. The results of these workshops are systematically documented, including key business decisions, process models, scope confirmations, delta requirements, and initial roadmap elements.

These findings are incorporated into the fit-to-standard documentation as well as into further planning and design workshops (e.g. on integration, extensibility, analytics, master data and security). The identified requirements are consolidated, checked and transferred into structured backlog items. All backlog items are then merged, prioritized, and tailored for the first implementation phase, while unplanned content remains documented for later releases.

Release planning prepares the transition to the realize phase , in which the backlog is implemented in sprints. In these iterations, the backlog items go through the cycle of configuration, review, and testing, so that the originally identified requirements are gradually turned into executable, tested, and professionally approved solution results.

 

The transition from SAP business processes to the program backlog follows a clearly structured, value-oriented approach in the context of SAP Activate and SAFe®. The starting point is the definition of the program vision and scope, in which business scenarios, end-to-end processes and technical target images are defined. This vision provides guidance for all subsequent backlog decisions.

Based on this, the product backlog is  defined by breaking down the processes into concrete process steps and  deriving initial user stories. These are prioritized,  bundled into features or releases and form the content basis for implementation. The next step is  to define Definition of Ready, Definition of Done, and the criteria for shippable deliverables to ensure a consistent understanding of quality and maturity across teams.

Finally, a high-level estimation and release planning is carried  out, in which feature sets are evaluated in story points and planned in iterations or sprints. This creates a resilient program backlog that creates transparency about scope, effort and delivery capability and enables reliable incremental implementation of business processes in SAP.

 

The slide describes how SAP Activate supports a multi-release deployment in SAFe® environments and how the SAP Activate phases closely align with the Planning Intervals (PIs) of an Agile Release Train or Large Solution Train. Each release corresponds to a PI and goes through the SAP Activate phases Discover, Prepare, Explore, Realize and Deploy before the delivered capabilities  are operationally used by the business in the run phase. Multiple releases build on each other incrementally, allowing for incremental value realization.

For Release 1,  the focus is on strategic alignment and foundation laying: innovation strategy, roadmap and value case are defined, governance and organization are established, end-to-end business scenarios are described, and requirements are transferred to a structured backlog via fit-to-standard workshops. Implementation takes place in agile sprints with reviews, tests and a controlled cutover or go-live.

Release 2 and subsequent releases follow the same pattern within subsequent PIs, with new or enhanced features being planned, implemented, and delivered as needed ("release on demand"). SAP Activate provides SAP-specific practices and accelerators – such as fit-to-standard, clean core governance along the Golden Rules, or the Solution Design Document – that effectively complement SAFe events such as PI planning, iterations, and reviews. The result is a consistent, scalable approach that reliably combines the planning, implementation, and operation of SAP solutions across multiple releases.

 

The slide shows the close integration of the SAP Activate Release phases with the SAFe® Development Value Stream and illustrates how SAP solutions are delivered incrementally and continuously via an Agile Release Train. SAP Activate structures the path to deployment via the Prepare, Explore, Realize, and Deploy phases, which extend over several sprints and are run through iteratively. Within the Realize phase, requirements are implemented, tested, and reviewed in a sprint manner, while Prepare and Explore serve as recurring, lightweight activities to refine scope, design, and planning.

On the SAFe side, this procedure corresponds to the Development Value Stream with the steps Define, Build, Validate and Release, which are repeated continuously and without re-initiating the project. SAP Activate thus integrates seamlessly into SAFe-ART operations: planning, development, validation, and delivery are continuous, releases are provided as needed, and business value is realized gradually. This combination enables a stable, scalable delivery structure in which SAP-specific methodology and SAFe principles work together consistently.

 

The slide illustrates that the originally linear sequence of SAP Activate with Prepare, Explore, Realize, and Deploy evolves into a cyclical, repeatable approach in a SAFe® environment  . Instead of going through the phases once sequentially, they are  applied again and iteratively within each Planning Intervals (PI). Each PI consists of several sprints in which planning, detailed clarification, implementation, testing and preparation for delivery are continuously intertwined.

SAP Activate remains the methodological framework for SAP-specific activities, while SAFe specifies the timing and scaling via planning intervals. Certain activities – in particular go-live preparation, cutover, data migration or integrative end-to-end testing – continue to follow a strict critical path and are often only meaningful or technically possible towards the end of a PI. Accordingly, releases or go-lives in SAP programs can often only take place at the PI end.

In summary, the illustration shows how SAP Activate does not lose agility in SAFe contexts, but is scaled in a structured way through the PI cycles: Planning, building, validation, and delivery are carried out continuously, while SAP-specific dependencies are neatly taken into account.

 

The example shows a SAFe® process for a single planning interval (PI) with productive go-live and illustrates how SAP Activate is seamlessly integrated into the PI process. The PI comprises the SAP activate phases Discover, Prepare, Explore, Realize, Deploy and Run, with a clear focus on the Realize phase with iterative implementation in several sprints.

At the beginning of the PI,  epics and lean business cases are sharpened in the Discover and Prepare context, the organization is prepared for the PI, systems are provisioned, and fit-to-standard workshops are planned. During PI planning, architecture decisions are made, backlogs are created for each agile team and the release scope is determined. In the Explore phase,  fit-to-standard workshops and design decisions concretize the business and technical requirements.

In the Realize phase, several Agile teams work in parallel along the end-to-end processes (e.g. Order-to-Cash, Travel-to-Reimburse, Hire-to-Retire). Backlog refinement and solution design workshops accompany the sprint implementation, while regular integration and solution demos ensure transparency and alignment. Towards the end of the PI,  the focus is on cutover planning, integration and final tests before the productive go-live takes place  with the PI release. The subsequent hypercare phase ensures stability and quick troubleshooting.

Recurring SAFe events such as Scrum of Scrums, PO and integration meetings,  and Solution Increment demos take place throughout the PI  . Overall, the example shows how SAP Activate embeds SAP-specific activities in a structured way in a SAFe Planning Interval cycle, thus enabling a controlled, incremental and production-ready go-live within a PI.

 

The second example shows a SAFe® process over several planning intervals (PIs) with only one productive release, a procedure that is particularly used for complex SAP transformations with high integration, test and cutover dependencies. In the first PI,  the focus is on content and technical preparation: building the MVP backlog, fit-to-standard and solution design workshops, architecture decisions and the iterative implementation of central end-to-end processes (e.g. order-to-cash, travel-to-reimburse, hire-to-retire) in several sprints. The results are typically delivered to a pre-production environment and validated as part of MVP evaluations without going live yet.

The second PI builds on these results. Backlogs are further refined, additional functionalities are added and stability, integration and quality are specifically increased. Fit-to-standard activities, architecture decisions and PI planning are carried out again, but with reduced initial effort, as the foundations have already been laid. Only at the end of this second PI does the consolidated release take place after production, followed by Hypercare.

This scenario illustrates how SAP Activate  enables incremental development across multiple PIs within SAFe  , while deliberately bundling the actual go-live. In this way, risks can be minimized, maturity level and business readiness increased, and at the same time the advantages of SAFe clocking and SAP-specific methodology can be optimally combined.

 

This slide complements Example 2 and shows the transition from the last realize PI to the production release as well as to stable run operation in a scenario with a go-live over several planning intervals.

In  PI n, the focus continues to be on realize: Backlog refinement and solution design workshops accompany the sprint implementation along the end-to-end processes (e.g. order-to-cash, travel-to-reimburse, hire-to-retire). At the same time, the cutover planning is  being prepared. Towards the end of the PI, integration and user acceptance tests follow, which ensure the professional and technical maturity level for the go-live. The actual release takes place "on demand" and leads to the cutover after production, followed by a structured hypercare phase.

With PI n+1,  the solution goes into run operation. The SAFe-agile cadence is intentionally maintained: sprints, scrum-of-scrums, PO/integration meetings, and solution-increment demos continue to run, enabling continuous value delivery. On this stable basis, functions can be expanded, optimized or modernized – along the transformation roadmap and current business needs. The application of the SAP Activate Five Golden Rules ensures that technological innovations are implemented in a controlled, clean-core-compliant and sustainable manner.

All in all, the presentation shows how SAP Activate and SAFe interlock seamlessly even after the go-live and consistently support the transition from project to product thinking.

 

In SAP projects, Scrum and Kanban are used in a complementary way to ensure transparency, focus and continuous flow in implementation. While Scrum specifies the timed framework for planning, implementation and review within a sprint, Kanban boards serve  to make the work in the sprint visible and to clearly present the current status of the backlog items – for example via columns such as To Do, In Progress, Under Review and Done. Swimlanes by team members or workspaces (e.g., configuration, setup) make accountability transparent. In addition, work-in-progress limits help to avoid overload and focus on a controlled number of tasks. Digital Kanban boards in ALM and backlog tools support distributed collaboration in particular and ensure consistent control across teams.

 

The architecture forms a central control and enabler function in SAP Activate and SAFe® environments. SAFe defines Agile Architectureas a set of values and practices that enables the continuous evolution of design and system architecture while incrementally implementing new capabilities. This understanding goes beyond classic architectural approaches and is closely linked to a DevOps mindset that supports rapid feedback cycles, automation and continuous improvement.

This understanding of architecture fits seamlessly into the SAP Activate methodology: In the Discover phase, the focus is on strategic architecture and transformation planning, in Prepare transition  and migration scenarios are specified and governance structures are defined, and the UX strategy is also defined in Prepare as an integral part of the solution architecture. Architectural decisions are not made once, but iteratively reviewed and adapted as requirements and solutions evolve.

Roles and responsibilities in the architecture context are consistently aligned across TOGAF, SAFe,  and the SAP Enterprise Architecture Framework. This common terminology and role logic facilitates collaboration between enterprise, solution, and system architects, ensuring that strategic guardrails, technical decisions, and agile execution are consistently connected.

 

Architecture in SAP Activate and SAFe® contexts includes enterprise, business, and technology architecture, and explicitly includes architectural governance and the architectural runway. Concepts from Open Agile Architecture™ (TOGAF), the SAP Enterprise Architecture Framework (EAF) and SAFe are coordinated with each other and create a common language for roles, responsibilities and decision-making mechanisms. The Architectural Runway describes the existing code, component, and infrastructure building blocks necessary to implement short-term features without costly redesign, making it a central enabler for continuous value delivery. SAP Activate operationalizes this understanding through clear architectural principles, governance structures, and technical readiness – for example, through continuous updates and upgrades, SaaS-by-default approaches, and predictable release cycles. Architecture is not understood as a static target image, but as a living, evolving foundation that accelerates innovation, ensures quality, and enables scaling in agile SAP programs.

 

The Architectural Runway describes the entirety of functional architectural building blocks, components and technical infrastructure that  enable continuous and fast delivery of business functionalities. In TOGAF or the SAP Enterprise Architecture Framework (EAF) as well as in SAFe,® the architectural runway is based on common core elements: clear architectural principles as guardrails, technical readiness to prepare for future requirements, and suitable governance mechanisms for control and quality assurance.

In SAFe®, however, this concept is explicitly understood as part of an Agile Architecture and follows a different governance model: The Architectural Runway is not a static artifact, but a collaborative, continuously evolving enabler. Architects consciously define an intentional architecture with clear guidelines, while agile teams  use emergent design to  expand and improve the architecture in a targeted manner as part of the feature implementation. The balance between the two approaches is crucial to ensure speed, maintainability and long-term stability. This makes architecture a shared responsibility of architects and teams and a central accelerator for sustainable, scalable SAP solutions.

 

Quality Built-In is a central principle of SAFe® and SAP Activate and ensures that quality is not checked at the end, but  integrated into every phase and increment from the very beginning. Built-in quality practices ensure that every solution element meets defined quality standards throughout development, enabling the organization to deliver new functionalities with minimal, sustainably sustainable turnaround time.

SAP Activate operationalizes this principle through clear guidelines for quality planning, implementation, and control, supported by formal quality gates, agile delivery methods, and end-to-end processes, content, and tools across the entire application lifecycle. A key lever is to start with SAP best practices, which provide executable, pre-integrated business processes and Fiori-UX and thus create stability and usability at an early stage. In addition, the fit-to-standard approach ensures that the solution is a professional fit and that necessary deviations are identified in a targeted and controlled manner.

In addition, SAP Activate is consistently  designed to be cloud-ready and supports modular, scalable, and agile implementation models that can be adapted to project size, complexity, and maturity. All in all, Quality Built-In combines methodological discipline with technical excellence and creates the basis for stable, adaptable and future-proof SAP solutions in SAFe® environments.

 

The slide specifies Quality Built-In as a multidimensional quality concept that SAP Activate and SAFe® jointly operationalize. The focus is  on flow as a fundamental principle: transparency about activities, clearly defined procedures and the use of best practices and "golden paths" ensure an even, predictable flow of value. Tests are an integral part of this across all levels of the testing pyramid and are clearly aligned with when and at what level testing is carried out.

Another focus is on Architecture & Design Quality. Reference architectures, standards, and binding design and implementation rules – in particular the SAP Activate Five Golden Rules – ensure long-term maintainability, future-proofing, and architectural consistency.

Code quality is ensured by clear development guidelines for SAP technologies, supporting tools, and technical and business testing. This makes quality visible at an early stage and continuously verifiable. In addition, System Qualityensures that the sum of the implemented features also functions stably as an integrated overall system.

The model is rounded off by release quality, which is ensured via continuous feedback loops, sprint reviews, integration and volume testing, and coordinated program governance. This creates a consistent understanding of quality in which architecture, development, testing, and release are intertwined, and quality remains a permanent component of the SAP solution – not only at the go-live, but throughout the entire life cycle.

 

The Golden Rules for the implementation of SAP S/4HANA with a cloud mindset define central guidelines to ensure quality, speed, and future-proofing in SAP programs. At its core is the fit-to-standard approach in combination with agile, incremental implementation in accordance with SAP Activate in order to make maximum use of SAP standard processes and shorten time-to-value. In addition, the use of pre-configured solutions such as SAP Best Practices and SAP Fiori UX is recommended to provide consistent processes and a modern user experience. For integration and expansion, the Golden Rules consistently rely on modern cloud technologies such as SAP BTP, APIs and ABAP-based, cloud-capable extensions, while reducing or replacing classic customer-specific modifications. Another key aspect is transparency in the event of deviations: Any deliberate deviation from the standard must be documented and made traceable using SAP ALM tools. Organizations that follow these rules benefit from lower implementation and operating costs, higher innovation capability, reduced project risk, and a flexible, future-proof SAP landscape with little reliance on customizations or individual integrators.

 

In SAP programs, shared services are  used to centrally provide specialized, cross-sectional services and efficiently support agile teams along the entire SAP Activate lifecycle. These services continuously accompany the phases from Discover to Run and ensure that critical skills are not fragmented in individual teams, but are provided consistently, scalably and quality-assured.

Typical shared services include IT service management and infrastructure operations, architecture governance via an architecture board, data cleansing and migration, custom code development, test planning and execution, solution design documentation, organizational change management, end-user training, and Enablement as well as security and authentication. Due to their central organization, these services relieve the burden on agile teams, reduce dependencies and increase transparency, quality and reusability.

In the SAFe® context, shared services act as an enabler for scaled agility by supporting multiple ARTs or teams at the same time while remaining in sync with the agile cadence. This ensures that SAP-specific requirements, governance requirements, and operational necessities are met without sacrificing the speed and ownership of teams.

 

SAP Fiori stands for a unified, user-centric user experience that effectively connects business, people, and technology. The focus is on the user: Through user-centric, inclusive, and design-driven UX design, SAP Fiori enables a consistent "One UX" across all SAP solutions and supports users in completing their tasks more easily and efficiently. At the same time, SAP Fiori addresses key business goals such as digitalization, process simplification, and cloud readiness. Technologically, Fiori is based on open web standards, service-oriented architectures, native mobile technologies and in-memory computing, creating high-performance, scalable and future-proof applications. In SAP Activate and SAFe® contexts, SAP Fiori is thus a central enabler for acceptance, productivity, and sustainable value realization.

 

The implementation of SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA is specifically simplified by SAP Activate providing structured tools and proven accelerators. At the beginning, the SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library supports  efficient initial scoping by identifying relevant Fiori apps per business process, role, and scenario. This creates clarity about the functional scope and the UX target architecture at an early stage.

For implementation, Rapid Activation ensures  fast and standardized delivery of the selected Fiori content, which significantly reduces configuration effort and implementation time. Finally, the targeted adaptation of the SAP Fiori Launchpad – for example via the Launchpad Content Manager – enables a role-based, needs-based design of the user interfaces. In this way, a consistent, efficient and user-centered UX is realized without unnecessary individualization, and the introduction of SAP Fiori is seamlessly integrated into the agile SAP Activate and SAFe® context.

 

This example shows how SAP Fiori UX is systematically used and anchored across all SAP Activate phases. The SAP Roadmap Viewer can be used to identify targeted UX-relevant activities  in the content of the SAP Activate Methodology for RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. By setting the "User Experience" filter, all deliverables, tasks and best practices that address UX aspects from Discover to Prepare and Explore to Realize become visible – such as UX scoping, UX planning, fit-to-standard preparation for Fiori features, UX design, and analytics and extension design.

This approach ensures that SAP Fiori is not viewed in isolation as a technical topic, but  is planned at an early stage, continuously refined, and consistently implemented. This makes UX an integral part of SAP transformation, supporting adoption, productivity, and business value across the entire lifecycle of S/4HANA cloud adoption.

 

The "Three Ways of DevOps" describe the fundamental principles that connect development (Dev) and operations (Ops) into an integrated, powerful value stream. The first way – Flow focuses on systems thinking and a continuous flow of value from the requirement to operation. The goal is to overcome silos, reduce bottlenecks and consistently align all IT-supported value streams with business goals.

The second way – Feedback Loops aims to quickly and continuously feed feedback from all stakeholders. Short feedback cycles between development, testing, operation and business enable early detection of problems and promote continuous improvement.

The third way – culture of continuous experimentation and learning creates the cultural framework for sustainable success. Through controlled experimentation, a willingness to learn and a constructive approach to mistakes, innovation is promoted and the organization is enabled to adapt quickly to change. Combined, these three paths form the foundation for DevOps practices that enable scalable, high-quality, and fast value delivery in SAP Activate and SAFe® environments.

 

The IT transformation according to the first path of DevOps – Flow focuses on the continuous flow of value from business needs to operations. Instead of silos, it promotes systems thinking, where all activities are aligned with the end-to-end business value streams . SAP Activate embodies this first DevOps path for SAP solutions particularly consistently, as it defines clear phases, roles, artifacts, and expectations, enabling a transparent, predictable, and continuous flow.

Across all SAP Activate phases – from Discover and Prepare to Explore and Realize to Deploy and Run – it is ensured that business goals, KPIs, UX strategy, architecture, security and lifecycle management are closely interlinked. Supported by integrated tools such as SAP ALM, SAP BTP, SAP Fiori, and Analytics, it creates a consistent value stream that empowers teams to deliver end-to-end business capabilities together. In this way, SAP Activate makes the DevOps principle of flow tangible and forms the methodological basis for scalable, value-oriented IT transformations in SAFe® environments.

 

The slide shows how DevOps, System Teams, and the SAP Customer Center of Expertise (CoE) work together to ensure end-to-end, scalable operational and delivery capability for SAP solutions. SAP Activate and the SAP ALM Suite provide the methodological and tool-side foundation for planning, implementation, and lifecycle management, while DevOps practices  enable flow, rapid feedback loops,  and a culture of continuous learning. System teams and SRE/operations units ensure platform stability, automation, monitoring, and incident management without slowing down agile teams. The SAP CoE acts as a connecting bracket for governance, architecture, standards, enablement, and knowledge transfer, ensuring consistency across programs, ARTs, and the entire solution lifecycle. All in all, an integrated model is created in which development and operation are not separated, but organized as a common value stream that enables sustainable innovation and stable business outcomes.

 

The slide shows how SAP ALM tools are used to  systematically document, control, and make the solution intent transparent. The Solution Intent serves as a central repository for the current and desired solution behavior and includes both fixed and variable specifications, architecture and design decisions, references to standards, system models as well as functional and non-functional tests including end-to-end traceability. In the SAP context, this approach is implemented through integrated application lifecycle management for the Intelligent Enterprise, which covers the entire lifecycle from design, build, test, and deploy to operation and optimization. Tools such as SAP Solution Manager, SAP Focused Run, SAP Cloud ALM, supplemented by SAP Signavio and SAP BTP, enable consistent documentation of the solution intent across programs, ARTs and teams, thus supporting governance, quality assurance and continuous development in SAFe® and SAP Activate environments.

 

SAP Cloud ALM is a modern, fully cloud-based application lifecycle management solution designed specifically for SAP cloud and hybrid scenarios. It supports the entire lifecycle of a solution – from implementation with process, task, test and deployment management to operationwith application, integration, user and business process monitoring as well as health checks. Based on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP Cloud ALM provides scalable platform services and central data management, and integrates seamlessly with adjacent disciplines such as IT service management, monitoring, test automation, deployment tools, document management, and collaboration via APIs. SAP Cloud ALM thus acts as a central control and transparency layer for SAP Activate, SAFe®, and DevOps, enabling consistent, standardized, and future-proof control of implementation and operation.

 

The slide makes it clear that the actual value of an SAP solution only arises through acceptance and efficient use in business. Organizational agility is therefore a key success factor in SAP Activate and SAFe® transformations. Change is not understood as a one-time event, but as a continuous process that extends over several planning intervals and releases.

Along the SAP Activate phases, organizations go through typical emotional curves – from initial shock and resistance to acceptance and learning to sustainable adoption. Targeted change measures, such as those supported by SAP Digital Change Advisory , can cushion emotional reactions, shorten learning phases and significantly accelerate acceptance. With each subsequent release, the resistance curve decreases, as employees are used to continuous change.

Organizational agility enables companies  to permanently anchor new ways of working, new forms of collaboration, new roles and new processes. In this way, change becomes a core competence of the organization – not as a burden, but as a prerequisite for continuous value realization and sustainable transformation success.

 

 The slide shows how a continuous and smooth business transformation is enabled  by the targeted integration of Digital Change Adoption into SAFe® and SAP Activate structures. At  the portfolio level, SAFe aligns with corporate strategy and creates a clear vision. This is  translated into a concrete project mission at the level of the Large Solution Train. Finally, SAP Activate and the Agile Release Train operationalize this orientation via multi-release deployments, in which change is brought into the organization gradually and in a controlled manner.

Change management is firmly integrated into the sprint work: In early sprints, the effects of change are analyzed, risk mitigation measures are defined, and the first MVPs for communication, training, and enablement are developed. In subsequent sprints, these change and learning products are implemented, rolled out, monitored and continuously adapted. This creates clear added value for the user community, which is communicated in an understandable way and made tangible.

This consistent cascade of strategy → mission → benefits for users creates a clear overall picture that connects all stakeholders. Change is not seen as an accompanying activity, but as an integral part of agile delivery – and thus an enabler for sustainable adoption, high acceptance and long-term transformation success.

 

 SAP Communities of Practice provide users, consultants, and developers with a central platform for knowledge sharing, best practices, and continuous learning about SAP solutions. The SAP Community gives practitioners access to field reports, discussions, blogs, Q&A formats, and current developments from real projects. Communities on SAP Activate and Application Lifecycle Management are particularly relevant for agile SAP programs, as they provide concrete assistance on methodology, governance, tools, and delivery. In addition, numerous other communities on solutions, specialist domains and development topics are available, which make it possible to network in a targeted manner, address challenges and drive innovations together.

 

 The SAP Business AI Approach describes how SAP integrates artificial intelligence into business processes systematically, practically, and responsibly. SAP provides a broad portfolio of AI-powered scenarios across all core business functions – from finance and supply chain to customer experience and procurement to human resources and IT and cross-functionalities. The approach follows clear guiding principles: relevant for specific business use cases, reliable through robust, enterprise-grade technologies, and responsible in terms of transparency, security, and governance.

Technically, SAP Business AI is based on a multi-layered architecture with embedded AI capabilities directly in SAP solutions (e.g., Cloud ERP, HCM, CRM, Spend Management), a common AI Foundation on the SAP Business Technology Platform,  and a strong ecosystem of technology partners. As a result, AI is not understood as an isolated innovation, but as an integrated enabler for better decisions, higher process efficiency, and sustainable business benefits in the SAP Activate and SAFe® context.

 

 

SAP Activate resources for agile teams

 

 

 The SAP Activate Adoption Roadmap for SAFe® teams describes a clearly structured way to gradually and effectively embed SAP Activate in the organization. The starting point is the enablement of the teams so that all participants develop a common understanding of SAP Activate, roles, artifacts and procedures. Building on this, roles and responsibilities in the SAP program will be sharpened and consistently aligned with the SAP Activate role models. In a next step, SAP activate processes and accelerators will be  used specifically in the program to accelerate planning, implementation, and governance. The introduction of SAP ALM tools ensures transparency, traceability, and end-to-end lifecycle management. Finally, adoption is completed through the consistent use of agile practices in SAFe – with backlogs, ARTs, and iterative planning, delivery, and quality assurance. Along these five topics, a pragmatic, prioritized roadmap is created that SAFe SAP teams can use to establish SAP Activate in a sustainable and value-oriented way.

 

 

 Customers access SAP Activate content through multiple, complementary channels that cover different phases and needs in the SAP lifecycle. The SAP Activate Roadmap Viewer is the central entry point for methodological guidance, roadmaps, deliverables, and accelerators along the SAP Activate phases. The SAP Signavio Process Navigator complements this with SAP best practices, reference processes and ready-to-run business content as the basis for fit-to-standard workshops. SAP Cloud ALM supports operational implementation by managing implementation activities, tracking implementation steps, and improving time-to-value and operational stability. In addition, the SAP Activate Community offers  continuous updates, blog posts, Q&A formats, and best practices to share experiences and continuously develop SAP Activate. Taken together, these access paths enable end-to-end, up-to-date and practical use of SAP Activate.

 

 

 It is crucial to consistently live SAP Activate with agile principles and to establish  a clear fit-to-standard mindset in order to reduce complexity and accelerate time-to-value. An early focus on data cleansing and migration minimizes risks in later stages, while organizational change management ensures that change is accepted and sustainably used. The targeted use of SAP ALM tools based on SAP Activate and best practices creates transparency, controllability, and quality over the entire life cycle. This is complemented by the use of the right, experienced resources, integrated, holistic planning including test automationand a clear strategic orientation. Taken together, these factors form the basis for a successful, predictable and sustainably effective SAP transformation.

entry.title: Re: The maintenance dialog for "Table/View name" is incom...
entry.content:
Hi @maheshmorabad ,
This error means the table/view maintenance dialog (used by IMG activities) is missing or corrupted. The fix is usually to regenerate the maintenance dialog in transaction SE54 (View/Table Maintenance Generator) for the affected table/view.

To fix the issue please follow below mentioned steps

Identify the Table/View: From the error message, note the Table/View name (e.g., V_T001, V_T005).
Confirm it’s a customizing view or subtable used in IMG.

Use SE54 (View/Table Maintenance Generator): Go to transaction SE54 (or SE11 → Utilities → Table Maintenance Generator). Enter the table/view name. Choose Create/Change.

Regenerate the maintenance dialog: Define Authorization Group (often &NC& for none).Set Function Group (usually the one SAP suggests). Save and activate.

Transport if Needed
If this is a customizing object, ensure the regenerated dialog is included in a transport request so it’s available in other systems.

Test
Run SM30 with the view name.

If the dialog opens correctly, retry the IMG transaction.

entry.title: Re: Question Regarding Allocation from Cost Center to Int...
entry.content:
Hi @Dai_Chiba ,
Yes, the inability to select internal orders as receivers in Fiori app F3338 is a standard limitation by design. The app supports only certain cost object types (e.g., cost centers, profit centers, margin analysis objects) under the Universal Allocation framework. Allocations from cost centers to internal orders must currently be executed via the SAP GUI transactions (e.g., KSU1/KSV1), as internal orders are not enabled as receivers in F3338

My recommendation to you as mentioned below.
Use SAP GUI for allocations from cost centers to internal orders.
Leverage Fiori F3338 for allocations involving cost centers, profit centers, and margin analysis objects.

Monitor SAP Notes / Roadmap: SAP occasionally extends Universal Allocation functionality; check if internal orders become supported in future releases.

Communicate to Users: Clarify that this is not a configuration issue but a design limitation, to avoid unnecessary troubleshooting

Hi @Andre_Fischer,

Thanks for this cool RAP generator app.

 

I tried to use it in our internal public cloud system, but unfortunately the app couldn't find fields: 'Data Source Name' and 'Package'. 
I've checked class: ZDMO_CL_RAP_GEN_GET_PACKAGE (used for package search) and also class: ZDMO_CL_RAP_GEN_GET_DATA_SRC_2 (used for data source name search).

Cheking ZDMO_CL_RAP_GEN_GET_PACKAGE  I found, that the query happens in CL_XCO_AR_SELECTION_DATABASE->execute_select( ) for table: TADIR and ARS_APIS_RELEASED_FOR_C1_SCP. 
For some reason in our system this select doesn't find anything, even if I execute it without including 'TADIR~OBJ_NAME LIKE' in the where condition.

Maybe we should somehow add entries in ARS_APIS_RELEASED_FOR_C1_SCP?
Could you please let me know what are the prerequisites of using this app properly?


One more small comment: Both classes have a little limitation, because in our case the search string doesn't contain leading and a trailing quotation mark, so currently it is not possible to search with a less then 3 character long string. 

Best regards,
Istvan

entry.title: Re: different e-mail adresses for sending purchase order...
entry.content:
Maintain one additional mail address and misuse field remark. e.g. BA (Bestelladresse) and GS (Gutschrift) 

MM-LIV Consignment settlements or ERS credit notes are always sent to the default mail address (Is hard coded) 
The GS Address should be marked as default address

Implement BADI BADI_MM_PO_OC_EMAIL - IF_BADI_MM_PO_OC_EMAIL~CHANGE_RECIPIENTS

DATA lv_smtp_addr TYPE ad_smtpadr.

SELECT SINGLE a~smtp_addr 
    INTO lv_smtp_addr
  FROM adr6 AS a INNER JOIN adrt AS b ON a~addrnumber = b~addrnumber AND
                                                                              a~persnumber = b~persnumber AND
                                                                              a~date_from = b~date_from AND
                                                                              a~consnumber = b~consnumber
                                INNER JOIN lfa1 AS c ON b~addrnumber = c~adrnr
WHERE c~lifnr = im_nast_entry-parnr AND b~remark = 'BA' AND b~comm_type = 'INT'. 

IF sy-subrc = 0.
    CLEAR cht_to_recipient_list. 
    APPEND lv_smtp_addr TO cht_to_recipient_list.
ENDIF.

entry.title: How to debug or trace validations and substitutions (GGB0, program GBTAAFI0, etc.)
entry.content:
How to debug or trace some validations and substitutions defined in the transactions GGB0, GGB1, etc., which use simple values, not user exits.

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: How to debug or trace validations and substitutions (GGB0, program GBTAAFI0, etc.)
entry.content:
When the validation and substitution rules are saved in GGB0, GGB1, etc., the customizing is converted into ABAP code and stored in programs dynamically generated.

The debug can be done in these programs via breakpoints as usual.

But the problem is to find out what the program names are. That's explained below.

The names of the generated programs start with GB. Different program names are used for each client where the rules are used, for instance the executable program of FI validations is GBTAAFI0 for the client 100 but GBTTQFI0 for the client 800.

The exact names of the executable and include programs GBTmmaa0 (or GBTccaa0) are determined as follows:

  • T
    • Always "T"
    • To be confirmed: possibly, it could be "S" for the module "RL" (although it's not in the list below)
  • mm (or cc)
    • Encoded client (by G_CLIENT_ENCODE)
      clients 000 ... 099 -> '00' ... '99'
      clients 100 ... 135 -> 'AA' ... 'AZ', 'A0' ... 'A9' (e.g. AA for client 100)
      clients 136 ... 171 -> 'BA' ... 'B9'
      clients 172 ... 207 -> 'CA' ... 'C9' (e.g. C2 for client 200)
      clients 208 ... 243 -> 'DA' ... 'D9'
      clients 244 ... 279 -> 'EA' ... 'E9'
      clients 280 ... 315 -> 'FA' ... 'F9' (e.g. FU for client 300)
      clients 316 ... 351 -> 'GA' ... 'G9'
      ... (e.g. TQ for client 800)
      clients 964 ... 999 -> 'YA' ... 'Y9'

      Conversion logic from the 2 characters to the client number (3 digits):
      Each character A to Z and 0 to 9 is assigned a number N from 1 to 36 (A=1, Z=26, 0 to 9= 27 to 36), N1 will be the number of the first character and N2 the number of the second character, the formula is:

      ( 36 * N1 ) + 63 + N2

      e.g.
      C2 -> N1 = 3 and N2 = 29 -> ( 36 * 3 ) + 63 + 29 = 200
      TQ -> N1 = 20 and N2 = 17 -> ( 36 * 20 ) + 63 + 17 = 800

      Conversion logic from the client number CCC (3 digits) to the 2 characters:
      N1 = ( CCC - 63 ) DIV 36 (integer division)
      N2 = ( CCC - 63 ) MOD 36 (modulo)

      e.g.
      200 -> N1 = round( 137 / 36 ) = 3 = "C" and N2 = modulo( 137 , 36 ) = 29 = "2" -> "C2"
      800 -> N1 = round( 737 / 36 ) = 20 = "T" and N2 = modulo( 737 , 36 ) = 17 = "Q" -> "TQ"

  • aa
    • Module code. FI for finance. The list of modules and their texts are defined in the table GB03T:
      AM Asset Accounting
      CO Cost Accounting
      CS SAP Consolidation
      FI Financial Accounting
      FM Funds Management
      FP Public Sector France
      GA FI-SL Allocation
      GL Special Purpose Ledger
      GR Report Writer
      GS Ledger Selection
      GU Rollup
      JV Joint Venture Accounting
      KC Enterprise Controlling - SAP EIS -
      LA Financing
      LC FI-LC Consolidation
      MC Management consolidation
      PC Profit Center Accounting
      PM Project-Oriented Materials Mgmt
      PS Project System
      RE Real Estate
      RL Reserved: Internal Usage
      RR Rule Processor for Rules
      RS Rule Processor for Substitutions
      RV Rule Processor for Validations
      WY Warranty
  • 0
    • 0 is for the main executable program, the below characters are used for the include programs.
    • A: Include program containing the rules of validations and substitutions (subroutines named CHK_SUBRULE_<rule name>)
    • B: Include program containing the substitutions defined in GGB1 (subroutine names prefixed SUB_; they call the subroutines of the C include program)
    • C: Include program containing the substitution conditions defined in GGB1 (subroutine names prefixed SUBCON_)
    • D : Include program containing the validations defined in GGB0 (subroutine names prefixed VAL_; they call the subroutines of the E and F include programs)
    • E: validation conditions defined in GGB0 (subroutine names prefixed VALCOND_)
    • F: validation checks defined in GGB0 (subroutine names prefixed VALCHCK_)
    • I: application rules currently empty in my system (TODO)
    • J: Include program containing the subroutines used to transfer only the substituted fields defined by the menu option Extras > Fields for substitution, in GGB1
    • M: Include program containing some fixed SAP subroutines for Trace/Simulation
    • S: Include program containing some fixed SAP subroutines for Substitutions
    • 0: Main ABAP program which includes all the include programs above

If you want to trace the ABAP code, you may look at the following function modules which call the validations and substitutions:

  • G_VSR_VALIDATION_CALL
  • G_VSR_SUBSTITUTION_CALL

If you want to see the code of the user exits and you don't know the main program name, you may go to the list of user exits in the screen of the check of the validation (GGB0) or substitution (GGB1), select the user exit and click the ABAP Editor button.

Be careful with the menu option Extras > Expert Trace > Set breakpoint in GGB0/1, it sets a Session Breakpoint, so it may not work via ADT and Fiori. Instead, you may prefer setting yourself a User/External Breakpoint via the ABAP Editor.

NB: the answer was also already given in the forum, blog posts or SAP Help Portal:

  • Question user exits and substitution - SAP Community
    • The note 842318 - Frequently asked questions about validations and substitutions - SAP for Me explains several things: how to trace, the structure of the generated ABAP code, how to debug it, etc.
  • SAP Help Portal A way that can quick debug into Validation or Substitution program | SAP Help Portal:
    • You may start the ABAP editor of the validations or substitutions directly from GGB0 or GGB1:
    • For validations, start GGB0, select your validation, enter =SHCD and press Enter, the ABAP editor opens at the start of the subroutine corresponding to the validation (named VAL_<validation name>). This subroutine contains the code for all the steps of the validation.
      • You may also use =SHCE and =SHCF to go respectively to the code of the condition and of the check.
      • =SHC0 to go to the main program
    • For substitutions, start GGB1, select your substitution, enter =SHCB and press Enter, the ABAP editor opens at the start of the subroutine corresponding to the substitution (named SUB_<substitution name>). This subroutine contains the code for all the steps of the substitution.
      • =SHC0 to go to the main program
  • SAP Help Portal Tracing a Validation/Substitution/Rule | SAP Help Portal
    • Menu Extras > Activate trace OR the below item Activate total trace. The first item activates the trace for the selected validation or substitution, whist the second activates it for all the validations and substitutions.
    • When you run the concerned validation or substitution via a dialog transaction code, a simulation screen appears each time it's triggered.
    • Be careful: it works well only if the trace is activated in the same SAP GUI External Session (in one or more modes of the windows of the same login). In ADT or Fiori, each execution runs in its own External Session, hence if you activate the trace in one window, the other one can't see the activation. The workaround in ADT and SAP GUI is to run everything in the same window: start SMEN to display the SAP menu, then run GGB0/1 to activate the trace, return to the menu, start the transaction code and its validation or substitution. The reason that it works only in the same External Session is because the trace is activated via SET PARAMETER ID 'GB1' FIELD '/X' (like the menu Activate total trace) or FIELD <validation/substitution name> (like the menu Activate trace). With Fiori, maybe one solution is to set GB1 yourself in your user parameters (SU3/SU01).
  • Blog post
    • Screenshots about =SHCB in GGB1: Substitution trouble shooting (debug) - SAP Community

If there are some errors, missing information or any modification needed, please tell me and I'll try to improve my answer.

Sandra
